newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian stocks lower, dullness to last.
newsitem.headline: Croatian stocks lower, dullness to last.

text.p: Croatian stocks closed mostly lower in somewhat brisker trade on Wednesday, but analysts foresaw no big developments on the market plagued by negligible demand.
"Almost all stocks show a downward trend...I don't think any sudden boom could happen in the near future," a trader with a large market share said.
He maintained demand was largely outstripped by offers, adding:
"People here don't hesitate to lower the prices....Also, some foreign investors fled to other growing markets," he said without elaborating further.
Of eight active issues, two were up, five down and two were up. Volume was higher at 1,470 shares, turnover also rose to 1.3 million kuna from Tuesday's meagre 865,305 kuna.
Top gainer drugs firm Pliva rebounded 400 kuna to close at 13,000, on volume of 54 shares.
The other gainer, Karlovacka Pivovara, inched up four kuna to 214, with 44 shares sold.
Zagrebacka Banka inched down five kuna to 1,000, with 141 shares changing hands. But traders said the bank was likely to resist the bearish trend, together with the other fully-listed issue, Pliva.
The biggest of the five decliners, hotelier Laguna, lost 100 kuna to close at 1,050, trading 39 shares.
The hotelier was closely followed by confectioner Kras which edged down 60 kuna to 450, but was the most actively traded issue on volume of 629 shares.
Food processor Podravka was also on the losing side, edging down 15 kuna to 200, selling 357 units. Hotelier Suncani Hvar slipped two kuna to 58, with 160 shares traded.
Only hotelier Arenaturist remained unchanged at 150 kuna, with 46 shares changing hands.
